topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
subtopic: Disclosure of Material Facts Affecting Property Value
question_text: Which of these transactions requires a selling broker to perform a reasonably competent visual inspection, according to California Civil Code Section 2079?
A: Sale of a four-bedroom ranch home
B: Sale of a home as ordered by a probate court
C: Sale of a six-unit apartment building
D: Transfer of a three-unit apartment building by a trustee in a bankruptcy
explanation: California code requires a selling broker to perform a reasonably competent visual inspection of the property for transfers of residential property of one-to-four units.

topic: Property Ownership and Land Use Controls and Regulations
question_text: A licensee works at a brokerage that deals primarily in a mountainous county in California. Which of the following questions would best help the licensee understand the environmental issues unique to the county?
A: Are any home owners in the county required to maintain defensible areas around their home?
B: How do dirt roads in these rural areas affect our sales?
C: What is the population density in the county?
D: What property that we've listed has the highest elevation?
explanation: Not all counties are affected by state requirements to maintain a defensible area around the home in case of fire, which makes this an important piece of information for a licensee to know.

topic: Financing
question_text: When consumers make a small down payment, borrow the remaining amount of the purchase price from a lender, and reap the rewards off of the full investment value, they are demonstrating what concept?
explanation: To leverage is to put up a small amount of money to obtain a loan of a larger amount.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: Which entity provides oversight for real estate transactions and regulations, including recordkeeping?
explanation: The California Department of Real Estate provides oversight for real estate transactions and regulations.

topic: Property Ownership and Land Use Controls and Regulations
question_text: Sam grants Steve a license to hunt deer on his property. Which of the following statements about the license is true?
A: Sam can revoke the license at any time.
B: The license is a permanent privilege.
explanation: A license is temporary, and at the discretion of the property owner. A license is not assignable or inheritable.

topic: Property Ownership and Land Use Controls and Regulations
question_text: A homebuyer decides to invest their small inheritance in real estate. They plan to add a building to immediately increase the value of the investment. Which economic characteristic of real property is this?
explanation: The economic characteristic of improvements says that a land's value can be influenced by changes that are made to it.

topic: Contracts
question_text: Which of the following describes a contract that exists based not on words, but on the parties' actions or behaviors?
explanation: A contract that's based on the parties' actions is implied, while a contract that's based on words, whether spoken or written, is express.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: What happens to a California real estate licensee if they are involved in a case and cannot pay the judgment amount, and the consumer is awarded money from the real estate Recovery Account?
A: Nothing! That is what the fund is for!
B: Their commissions will be garnished until the amount paid out to the victim is repaid.
C: Their license will be suspended until they pay back the amount paid to the victim, plus interest.
D: They can continue to practice real estate, but must pay back the amount paid out, plus interest.
explanation: Licensees must pay back any amounts paid out from the account, plus interest. Their license will be suspended until the amount is repaid.

topic: Transfer of Property
question_text: A homeowner owned an acreage in a rural area. They sold a small portion of it to a neighbor in an informal transaction but made no record of the sale or change of ownership. A developer offered the homeowner several million dollars for the entire acreage, and they eagerly accepted the offer. What covenant is the homeowner in danger of violating?
explanation: The covenant of seisin guarantees that the grantor owns the property that appears in the deed. Because the sale of property to Ari's neighbor was never recorded, his deed still shows that he owns the entire parcel.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
subtopic: Disclosure of Material Facts Affecting Property Value
question_text: Which of the following scenarios describes information that a licensee must disclose?
A: The licensee heard a rumor that the city may buy houses on the street next year to build a freeway ramp.
B: The licensee learned that the property had a tax reassessment last year.
C: There are community-wide rumors that the property in question is haunted.
D: The seller didn't disclose any leaks, but the licensee sees moisture on the basement floor.
explanation: Any information a licensee knows about the physical condition of a property, or information that could be plainly noticed even if the seller doesn't disclose it, should be disclosed.

topic: Property Valuation and Financial Analysis
question_text: Which one of the following best describes the state of the market during the recession phase of the real estate cycle?
A: High but stabilized unemployment and a high number of foreclosures
B: Increases in hiring, employment, and public confidence, and lots of buyers in the market
C: Properties selling for more than they're worth, many buyers in the market, and lots of new construction
D: Unemployment increasing, prices falling, and foreclosures on the rise
explanation: During the recession phase, fewer buyers and increased unemployment can lead to an increase in foreclosures.

topic: Laws of Agency and Fiduciary Duties
question_text: Kamut met with Amy, a buyer, and showed her his new listing. If Amy is unrepresented, did Kamut err by not providing Amy with an agency disclosure?
A: No, because he is the listing agent
B: Only if Amy asked for advice or offered confidential information
C: Yes, because any time you meet with a buyer, you must provide agency disclosure
D: Yes, because he showed her property
explanation: Unless their conversation strayed into dangerous territory, this situation does not require that an agency disclosure be provided.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: What is the purpose of the fair lending notice?
A: To disclose the demographic characteristics of approved mortgagors by the bank over the past five years.
B: To explain that financial institutions have the right to refuse to provide loans on homes in neighborhoods with historically high rates of foreclosure.
C: To notify mortgagors of their rights to equitable interest rates.
D: To notify mortgagors that it is illegal for financial institutions to discriminate on the basis of a protected class or on the basis of the characteristics of the neighborhood.
explanation: The purpose of the fair lending notice is to notify mortgagors that it is illegal for financial institutions to discriminate on the basis of a protected class or on the basis of the characteristics of the neighborhood.

topic: Property Ownership and Land Use Controls and Regulations
question_text: Kelvin isn't sure how to read this legal description, but his agent said something about reading it from right to left. Here's the description: "The north half of the northwest quarter of Section 6, Township 8 North, Range 68 west of the 5th principal meridian." What land description method did surveyors use for this piece of property?
explanation: Legal descriptions that use the RGSS usually include the state, name of the principal meridian, township, and range designations with compass directions and section numbers.

topic: Property Valuation and Financial Analysis
question_text: Which of the following actions toward an appraiser would be considered proper?
A: Asking an appraiser to correct errors in the appraisal report
B: Making payment of an appraisal report conditional on the value or estimate to be reached
C: Threatening to no longer do business with an appraiser
D: Withholding payment for a completed appraisal report
explanation: Real estate licensees can ask appraisers to correct errors in reports. This is a proper action. They cannot, however, withhold or threaten to withhold payment based on an appraisal report or make that payment conditional upon reaching a certain value.

topic: Property Ownership and Land Use Controls and Regulations
question_text: Which act requires developers to acquire a permit before development in a coastal zone?
explanation: The California Coastal Act requires developers to obtain a permit before development can occur in a designated coastal zone.

topic: Financing
question_text: What is a loan origination fee?
A: A fee a lender charges for processing a loan
B: A fee a lender charges for servicing a loan
C: A fee a lender charges for the use of its money
D: A fee a lender charges when a borrower pays off a loan
explanation: A loan origination fee is a fee a lender charges for processing, or initiating, a loan.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
subtopic: Disclosure of Material Facts Affecting Property Value
question_text: While showing your buyers through a home, you flipped on the light in the powder room and were concerned because the light switch felt warm. Why is this a concern?
A: Warm light switches might mean the house doesn't cool well.
B: Warm light switches might mean the house doesn't heat well.
C: Warm light switches might mean there is an electrical problem.
D: Warm light switches might mean there is a structural problem.
explanation: A light switch that's warm to the touch may be a sign of a fault or defect in the electrical system and should be checked out by an expert immediately.

topic: Financing
question_text: The ______ was enacted in 2010 to create stricter regulation of the financial services industry to reduce costs for consumers from (for instance), undisclosed kickbacks.
A: Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act
explanation: The aim of the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act was to regulate the financial services industry more effectively.

topic: Financing
question_text: Stacey's lengthy military service makes her uniquely eligible for a(n) ________.
explanation: Individuals eligible for VA loans include military members who have served 181 days on active duty or three months during war time.

topic: Property Ownership and Land Use Controls and Regulations
question_text: Homes built in which one of the following years are more likely to have asbestos present?
explanation: Homebuilding materials that contain asbestos are more likely to be found in homes built prior to the 1980s.

topic: Contracts
question_text: Which of the following elements is always required for a real estate contract to be valid?
explanation: For a contract to be legally binding, an offer and an acceptance must be supported by consideration, which is defined as something of value offered by both parties. Earnest money is one type of consideration, but earnest money isn't required for a contract to be valid.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
subtopic: Permitted Activities of Unlicensed Sales Assistants
question_text: Which of the following tasks would require a real estate license in California?
D: Place a for sale sign in a front yard
explanation: Administrative tasks are fine, but anything that involves activities normally performed by a licensee (such as meeting with the public to show real estate) would require a license.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
subtopic: Disclosure of Material Facts Affecting Property Value
question_text: Why should buyers ask sellers of older homes whether they've replaced the wiring system?
A: Because out-of-date electrical wiring can cause a wide a variety of problems.
B: Because the buyer will be required to update the wiring if it's more than 10 years old.
C: Because the seller will be required to update the wiring if it's more than 10 years old.
D: Buyers shouldn't ask about the wiring.
explanation: Out-of-date wiring can cause a variety of problems and could be unsafe. Buyers will want to investigate any electrical issues.

topic: Laws of Agency and Fiduciary Duties
question_text: Listings for sale or lease involving ______ to ______unit residential and commercial properties require agency disclosure in California.
explanation: Agency disclosure is required for listings for sale or lease involving one to four unit residential properties and non-residential (commercial) properties.

topic: Contracts
question_text: Which of these groups of people are considered legally able to enter into a contract in California?
explanation: Parties who may enter into a contract include emancipated minors, aliens, individual proprietors, partnerships, limited liability companies, corporations, nonprofit associations, personal representatives, and convicts.

topic: Transfer of Property
question_text: Marsha's title insurance policy was issued on closing day, which was June 18. The policy lists the standard exclusions as well as requirements for the company to issue the policy, such as paying off existing recorded liens. Which one of these will NOT be addressed in the schedule of exceptions?
A: Marsha's second mortgage on the property, which she plans to get next January
B: Marsha's unrecorded lease on the property
C: Smith and Martin Building and Rehab's mechanic's lien, which was filed on June 18
D: The local cable company's unrecorded easement through the property for underground wiring. Marsha disclosed this to the title company
explanation: Title insurance typically covers events or claims filed on the public record before the title insurance policy's effective date but excludes disclosed and undisclosed easements.

topic: Property Ownership and Land Use Controls and Regulations
question_text: What's the best definition of personal property?
A: Artificial attachments to land that include things such as fencing, buildings, and walkways
explanation: Personal property is everything that's not real property.

topic: Property Ownership and Land Use Controls and Regulations
question_text: What makes an income tax lien different from a property tax lien?
A: An income tax lien has priority over a property tax lien and will be paid first upon foreclosure.
B: An income tax lien is a general lien and a property tax lien is a specific lien.
C: An income tax lien is placed by the federal government and a property tax lien is placed by the state.
D: An income tax lien is voluntary and a property tax lien is involuntary.
explanation: An income tax lien is an example of a general lien because it's a lien against all of the person's assets, while the property tax lien is a lien on the real property for which the tax was assessed.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: Which of these actions is legal?
A: A landlord offers an apartment to a woman only if she goes out with him.
B: A landlord refuses to show or rent an apartment to someone who is not Christian.
C: A landlord requires a larger deposit for each child who will be living in the home.
D: A man advertises for a roommate to share his two-bedroom apartment and specifies that he prefers female roommates.
explanation: If the housing is an apartment or house with a shared common living area, a preference for sex may be advertised.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
subtopic: Disclosure of Material Facts Affecting Property Value
question_text: The Notice of Airport disclosure is required because _____________.
A: Buyers may want to rent an airplane hangar if the airport is nearby
B: Many commuters appreciate living near an airport
C: Noise and vibrations from airplanes can be disturbing to those living under or near the flight paths
D: The airport may need to expand in the future, requiring homes to be demolished
explanation: The proximity of an airport is a required disclosure because it can create stress in those exposed to the noise and vibration on a regular basis.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: While showing a property to your buyer client, you notice that new carpet was recently installed in the basement, and new paneling has been tacked to the walls. You know this is often something sellers do when they want to cover up evidence of water damage. You are ethically obligated to ______.
A: Point this out to your buyer client, and suggest she have an inspector look into this if she's interested in the property
B: Point this out to your buyer; inform her that the sellers are clearly hiding water damage, and tell your client that if the sellers are lying about this you cannot guess what else they're lying about
C: Report the sellers' agent to the local board and file an ethics complaint
D: Report the sellers to the local board and file an ethics complaint against them
explanation: You should inform your buyers of pertinent and relevant facts that may affect their decision to purchase, but should not claim to be qualified as an inspector.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
subtopic: Disclosure of Material Facts Affecting Property Value
question_text: Inconsistent temperatures from room to room is a common indication of a problem with what system or home feature?
explanation: Hot and cold rooms could be the result of duct problems or a room without a temperature control. These are heating- and cooling-related items.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: You're posting a listing on the MLS. Which of the following are you allowed to do according to most MLS guidelines?
A: Post the listing without a photo
C: State that a property is "one block" from downtown, if it is
D: Withhold the listing for two weeks prior to posting it on the MLS
explanation: It's not okay to self-promote. The idea is cooperation and marketing the listing, not yourself. It's also not okay to withhold the listing from the MLS unless the seller approves this in writing. Usually one exterior shot is required, at a minimum.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: What's market allocation?
A: Agreeing with a competing firm on how to split a market
B: Deciding to own the market with aggressive marketing strategies
C: Deciding which clients you will work with, and which you won't
D: Partnering with a branch office to dominate a market
explanation: Antitrust violations usually involve agreements between competitors.

topic: Property Ownership and Land Use Controls and Regulations
question_text: What's required in order for a homeowner to receive a $7,000 exemption on property tax?
A: The property may not be secured by a mortgage lien.
B: The property owner may not own other real property in the state.
C: The property owner must be a veteran.
D: The property owner must reside in the home.
explanation: Homeowners qualify for the property tax exemption of $7,000 if they reside in the home. It's a reduction in the property's assessed value.

topic: Financing
question_text: Which of the following describes amortized debt?
A: Debt that increases over time, but allows early payments to remain low
B: Debt that's paid off by making periodic payments
C: Debt with an amortized interest feature
D: Debt with an amortized principal feature
explanation: These periodic payments consist of both principal and interest.

topic: Financing
question_text: The mortgage and the deed of trust are ______ that pledge property as collateral for a loan.
explanation: The security instrument pledges the property as collateral for the loan, which is described in the promissory note.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: If your license is suspended, it's only temporary. If your license is revoked, it is permanently removed and requires ______.
B: A new license application after the penalty period
explanation: If your license is revoked, you must wait out any designated penalty period before you can apply for a new license.

topic: Contracts
question_text: A buyer backed out of a deal, and the seller kept the earnest money deposit. What is this an example of?
explanation: All of the answer options are actual remedies to breach of contract, but in this scenario, the seller kept the earnest money, which is known as accepting liquidated damages.

topic: Financing
question_text: From a lender's perspective, what does a credit score on the low end indicate?
explanation: A credit score is a number ranging between 300 and 850. The lower the number, the higher the risk.

topic: Property Ownership and Land Use Controls and Regulations
question_text: The Kelo vs. City of New London U.S. Supreme Court ruling was controversial because the U.S. Constitution prohibits the government from taking private property except for "public use." What governmental power was central to this case?
explanation: Kelo vs. City of New London focused on the power of eminent domain. It ruled that cities can take private property to promote private economic development.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
subtopic: Disclosure of Material Facts Affecting Property Value
question_text: Diana is selling her condominium. She has a responsibility to ________to the buyer.
A: Disclose all material facts about the property
D: Show her condo in its best light
explanation: In California, sellers have a responsibility to disclose all material facts about the property to the buyer. In a caveat emptor state, this disclosure responsibility is not as strict, and the onus is on the buyer to discover material defects.

topic: Contracts
question_text: Which of these statements accurately describes the purpose of a real estate option agreement?
A: Creates the option to buy a property in the future, within a specific time frame and at a particular price
B: Obligates the buyer to enter into a purchase agreement by a specific date
C: Provides a lessee, or renter, with the option to purchase the rented property at any time during the tenancy
D: Used by an investor to open a stock options account with an investment broker
explanation: The option agreement creates the option (but not obligation) to buy a property in the future at a particular price, and the contract requires a time frame or "option period."

topic: Laws of Agency and Fiduciary Duties
subtopic: Responsibilities of Agent to Seller/Buyer as Principal
question_text: To whom does a licensee owe the duty of disclosure of material facts?
D: The seller or buyer, if they are customers
explanation: Disclosure of material facts is required for all parties, whether they're represented or not.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: Randy, a broker, regularly places his client's trust funds in the firm's general business account, noting "trust fund" on the ledger. What is the problem with this approach?
A: They must be placed in an interest-bearing account.
B: They must be placed in a trust fund bank account or neutral escrow.
C: They must go into a separate general business account.
D: They should not be marked "trust fund."
explanation: Trust funds must be held in accounts separate from personal and business funds to be in compliance with commissioner's regulations and the Business and Professions Code.

topic: Contracts
question_text: A subcontractor missed several key deadlines, and the homeowner lost money waiting for the work to be completed. The homeowner consulted an attorney and terminated the contract. What is this an example of?
explanation: In this example, the homeowner rescinded the contract unilaterally as a means of remedying the breach of contract.

topic: Property Ownership and Land Use Controls and Regulations
question_text: Your client is developing a subdivision of 140 houses. They may place deed restrictions on as many as ______ properties.
explanation: Deed restrictions can be placed on an individual property, an entire subdivision, or a neighborhood.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
subtopic: Need for Inspection and Obtaining/Verfiying Information
question_text: Why is a home inspection recommended?
A: It gives the buyer a snapshot in time of the home's condition.
B: It helps the buyer identify cosmetic changes that must be made.
D: It's required by law for most residential transactions.
explanation: A home inspection is recommended for all residential real estate transactions as a way for the buyer to be fully informed about the property's condition. Inspections reveal material defects of a property, so buyers know exactly what they're buying.

topic: Transfer of Property
question_text: Which ownership type is defined by four unities: time, title, interest, and possession?
explanation: This is joint tenancy. Tenancy by the entirety requires a fifth unity (person). If one joint tenant dies, that tenant's interests go to the remaining joint tenants. If only one tenant is left, that tenant owns the property in severalty.

topic: Transfer of Property
question_text: Three sisters owned a vacation home two blocks from the beach. Sadly, one sister passed away over the winter, so when summer arrived, the other sisters shared the home with a nephew, to whom one sister willed her share of the property. What type of ownership is this?
explanation: This is a form of shared ownership, but only tenancy in common provides for inheritability-the other forms share the rights of survivorship (the existing tenants assume the deceased's share of the property).

topic: Property Ownership and Land Use Controls and Regulations
question_text: In which type of common interest subdivision are the owner's shareholders in a corporation that owns the property?
explanation: A stock cooperative, which can be an apartment, office, store, or other type of building, is owned by a corporation, and owners own a share in the property through it. Each receives an exclusive occupancy of a portion of the property.

topic: Transfer of Property
question_text: Which type of ownership termination allows each tenant to have a specific, divided portion (partition) of the property exclusively?
explanation: Termination of tenancy in common by partition allows each tenant to have a specific, divided portion of the property exclusively. If the property can't be divided, the court may rule that the property be sold, and the proceeds divided by the tenants.

topic: Laws of Agency and Fiduciary Duties
question_text: Jenson signed a seller agency agreement with Susan. Right before closing, a hurricane destroyed the property. What happened to Jenson and Susan's agreement?
A: It's terminated once the specified term in the agency agreement expires.
B: Jenson and Susan can mutually agree to terminate the agreement.
C: The agreement terminates by force of law.
D: The client can revoke the agreement but may be considered in breach of contract.
explanation: Because the property was destroyed, the listing agreement terminated by force of law.

topic: Transfer of Property
question_text: What's a quiet title action?
A: A lien placed against a potential land owner for property purchased by another
B: An action to locate and notify all who may have some claim on the title, and determine the validity of all claims
C: A type of title insurance that reimburses the policyholder if the neighborhood is noisier than normal
D: A way to anonymously purchase property without filing the title or transfer on record
explanation: A quiet title action involves locating a person who may have some claim on the title and determining the validity of any claims on title.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: When Tara is working with a client to sell his mountain cabin, she asks the client to complete the Seller Property Questionnaire and the TDS. The seller says, "But we haven't received any offers yet." What can Tara tell him about the timing required for providing the TDS?
A: The TDS is required to be submitted when the property is listed.
B: The TDS is required to complete the agency agreement, and must be completed as soon as possible.
C: The TDS must be available to prospective buyers at least 10 days prior to the acceptance of any offer.
D: The TDS should be submitted as soon as is practicable.
explanation: The TDS must be completed as soon as is practicable and certainly before the execution of any sales contract or transfer of title. The residential purchase agreement requires disclosures be provided no later than seven days after offer acceptance.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: Carla's landlord raised her rent 12% over the previous year's rental rate and gave her 45 days' notice. Was this legal under California's Tenant Protection Act?
A: No; landlords may not raise rents more than 10% annually.
B: No; the landlord may not raise rents more than 5% annually.
C: Yes, as long as he gives Carla 30 days notice of the increase.
D: Yes, provided the landlord gives Carla the option to move into a less expensive unit.
explanation: The Tenant Protection Act of 2019 prohibits annual rental increases of more than 5% plus the cost of living, and in no case more than 10%.

topic: Property Ownership and Land Use Controls and Regulations
question_text: What is an abandoned or unused commercial or industrial site that contains suspected contaminants?
C: A space that cannot be used
explanation: A brownfield is an abandoned or otherwise unused commercial or industrial site with suspected contaminants.

topic: Property Ownership and Land Use Controls and Regulations
question_text: Which type of subdivision is defined as separately owned parcels where purchasers also share interest in common areas?
explanation: Remember, common interest subdivision purchasers share a portion of the subdivision and hold equal interest in those common areas, but retain some exclusive right to access, use, or occupy the property.

topic: Contracts
question_text: Jayne was tired of waiting for her subcontractor to get his part of the deal done. The agreed-upon deadlines came and went, and Jayne lost money waiting for the subcontractor to come through. She decided that if the subcontractor weren't going to honor his commitments, neither was she, so Jayne consulted with her attorney and then terminated the contract. This is an example of ______.
explanation: In this example, Jayne rescinded the contract unilaterally as a means of remedying the breach of contract.

topic: Property Valuation and Financial Analysis
question_text: Which of the following is the cost of replacing a building in the case of total loss?
explanation: Insured value should be the cost of replacement in the event the property's destroyed.

topic: Transfer of Property
question_text: Which document is used to give a buyer an overview of the title history and information about what is or isn't covered in a title insurance policy?
explanation: Title insurance companies issue a preliminary report with the current title history and any liens or encumbrances. It outlines what the insurance company will or won't cover on its forthcoming insurance policy if the title is found to be acceptable.

topic: Financing
question_text: Which of the following describes a buydown?
A: ABC Lending charges origination points and offers a 4.5% rate.
B: Buyers pay the seller a prepaid lump sum prior to closing to reduce the sales price.
C: Your clients opt to pay their lender two discount points in a lump sum so they can lock in a reduced interest rate.
D: Your sellers pay some of the buyer's closing costs so the buyer can put more money to their down payment.
explanation: With a buydown, the borrower pays a lump sum to the lender to buy down the interest rate, lowering their monthly payment.

topic: Financing
question_text: Which of the following is a borrower eligibility requirement for CalHFA?
B: Doesn't intend to reside in the home for the length of the loan
D: U.S. citizen, permanent resident, or qualified alien
explanation: The borrower must be a U.S. citizen, permanent resident, or qualified alien. The borrower must live in the home being purchased for the duration of the loan term (or until the home is refinanced or sold).

topic: Transfer of Property
question_text: How may a buyer's title be vested through escrow?
B: As an estate in severalty or co-ownership
D: As an officiate of the state
explanation: A buyer takes title through escrow in the same way as in other transactions, as an estate in severalty, or co-ownership. It could even be vested as a corporation, limited liability company, or partnership.

topic: Financing
question_text: Rachel loves convenience. As you can imagine, she was thrilled when she was able to finance her mortgage through the same institution where she deposits her payroll checks. Which of these most likely financed Rachel's mortgage?
explanation: Thrifts, or savings and loan associations, specialize in taking in savings deposits and then lending money out to consumers through mortgages and other loans.

topic: Contracts
question_text: Which of the following advance fees is legal?
A: Bart, a licensee, receives an advance fee directly from his principal after having the advance fee agreement approved by California DRE.
B: Homer, a licensee, receives an advance fee from his client, Edna Krabapple. He does not report this to his broker.
C: Lisa, a licensee, receives approval for her advance fee agreement from California DRE and is paid through her broker.
D: Marge, a licensee, uses an advance fee agreement obtained through a stationery form and does not submit it to California DRE for approval, but is paid through her broker.
explanation: All compensation to licensees for real estate services must go through the licensee's broker.

topic: Property Ownership and Land Use Controls and Regulations
question_text: A home inspector is walking the lot of the property they are inspecting with a survey in hand. Which of the following will they note as an encroachment on the inspection report?
A: A neighbor builds a deck on their property in full view of the subject property.
B: The apple tree on the adjacent property drops apples onto the subject property.
C: The city seized the neighboring property to be used in a street widening project.
D: The neighbor installed a basketball hoop next to their driveway, six inches over the property line.
explanation: An encroachment occurs when someone illegally places a structure or object on another person's property, like a basketball hoop.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
subtopic: Disclosure of Material Facts Affecting Property Value
question_text: Yolanda purchased a house from the Griffins 10 months ago. Shortly after she moved in, the city began work on building a middle school on the empty lot right across the street. She feels that the city's plans must have been known to the Griffins and should have been disclosed, and she really doesn't want to live across the street from a school. Is it too late for her to take legal action against the Griffins?
A: No, Yolanda can take legal action against the buyers at any time while she still owns the property.
B: No, Yolanda can take legal action at any time within two years after taking possession of the property.
C: Yes, the buyer can only take legal action within six months of taking possession of the property.
D: Yes, Yolanda should have canceled the contract within three days of receiving seller disclosures.
explanation: Buyers must take legal action for breach of duty within two years of taking possession of the property.

topic: Transfer of Property
question_text: What is the requirement for escrow instructions provided by principals to a transaction in California, regardless of the location within the state?
A: The instructions must be clear and unambiguous.
B: The instructions must be issued bilaterally.
C: The instructions must be issued unilaterally.
D: The instructions must be signed by all parties and their agents, if represented.
explanation: Escrow instructions must be clear and unambiguous. They're typically issued bilaterally in northern California, and unilaterally in southern California. They must be signed by the principals, but not by their agents.

topic: Property Ownership and Land Use Controls and Regulations
question_text: Which legal description method is regulated by the U.S. Department of the Interior's Bureau of Land Management?
explanation: The U.S. Department of the Interior's Bureau of Land Management regulates the rectangular survey system.

topic: Contracts
question_text: If two parties enter into a contractual agreement with each other to perform an illegal act, which of the following statements is true of the contract?
A: It is voidable, because Jesse is not mentally competent to sign a contract.
B: It is voidable, because Jesse probably signed it under duress.
C: It is voidable, because the consideration, as a percentage rather than a dollar amount, is not clearly stated.
D: It is void because it is not for a lawful purpose.
explanation: A contract for an illegal purpose is void, and a void contract has no legal force or effect.

topic: Property Ownership and Land Use Controls and Regulations
question_text: A tenant rents a single-family home from its owner. What type of interest does the tenant have in the property?
explanation: Tenants have a leasehold interest in the property.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: Joanie sees herself as a mover and shaker, a leader, someone who jumps in and gets things done. She likes to be involved and in charge. When she decides to start investing in real estate, which of these choices is she most likely to select as her investment vehicle?
C: A real estate mortgage investment conduit
explanation: Since Joanie seems like an active, hands-on sort of person, she's most likely to choose a residential income property where she'll be in charge of the property rather than passive options like a REIT, REMIC, or syndicate.

topic: Property Ownership and Land Use Controls and Regulations
question_text: Dorcas and Ralph were married for 15 years. Ralph, an accountant, always took care of the bills and other financial matters for the couple. Then Dorcas discovered that Ralph had failed to pay the property tax on their property for the last three years. Which of these is likely to happen?
A: Dorcas and Ralph will be required to sell their home to the state for the amount of property tax owed.
B: The state will place a condemnation order on their property so they can't transfer their property until the debt is satisfied.
C: The state will place a mortgage lien on their home for the amount of property tax owed.
D: The state will place a tax lien on their property so it can't be transferred without satisfying the debt.
explanation: A real property tax lien is placed against property owners who have not paid their property taxes.

topic: Contracts
question_text: Francine's landlord never returned her security deposit after she moved, even though it was in writing that she would get it back within three weeks. How long after the deadline for returning the deposit does Francine have to sue, according to California's statute of limitations?
explanation: California's statute of limitations allows up to four years to sue for breach of a written contract. Oral agreements have a deadline of two years.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: Greg tries hard to reduce his carbon footprint, so he doesn't own a car. He's able to do all his shopping at stores on the same street where he lives, and takes a convenient train to his office for work. What type of community does Greg likely live in?
explanation: Greg's lifestyle is possible because he lives in a community designed as mixed use, with residential and retail properties on the same street, and with a transit-oriented design so catching a train to work is easy.

topic: Laws of Agency and Fiduciary Duties
question_text: Sue believes she's about to get into an undisclosed dual agency position. What should she do?
A: Inform all parties to the transaction
explanation: This is important to know! Licensees must avoid getting into an undisclosed dual agency position, and should inform the parties immediately if it appears that dual agency is about to occur.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: You've started creating your own advertising. Where can you look for reliable information?
explanation: In addition to DRE rules, regulations, and guidelines, and the NAR Code of Ethics, this is a good place to look.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: Early in its history, the Federal Housing Administration officially supported the practice of denying mortgage loans in predominantly Black neighborhoods. What is this practice known as?
explanation: Although redlining is now an illegal practice, the FHA initially supported it.

topic: Property Ownership and Land Use Controls and Regulations
question_text: Pamela inherited a piece of property that has been in her family for generations. She wants to find the property's exact boundaries. What should contain this information?
B: A legal description of the property
C: A satellite image of the property
D: Old family photos of the property
explanation: A legal description precisely locates the property and its boundaries.

topic: Contracts
question_text: Why is it so necessary to obtain signatures on a listing agreement?
A: Any real estate contract must be in writing to be enforceable.
B: Every blank needs to be filled in on a form contract.
C: Signatures are required to list the property on the MLS.
D: Your broker may be fined for approving a listing agreement that is not signed.
explanation: Any real estate contract must be in writing to be enforceable. It's possible to have a legal listing agreement that's only been committed to orally, but if you were ever to go to court to try to enforce it, you'd be out of luck.

topic: Property Ownership and Land Use Controls and Regulations
question_text: Licensee Arlene is helping a client purchase a property that's suitable for use as a private school, meaning it needs to have classrooms, assembly rooms, and sports fields. She locates two properties in the area that have the required attributes. What category of property is this considered?
explanation: Special purpose properties include hospitals, churches, and schools.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: Helen is a California broker who keeps a trust account for her brokerage. Each month she reviews the trust account records provided to her by her accountant. Which of these records would NOT be part of her review of proper trust fund handling?
explanation: Helen's review of trust account records would include the journal, cash ledger, and beneficiary ledgers for the trust account. Beneficiary journals aren't part of standard accounting records.

topic: Financing
question_text: With a land contract, who retains the title to the property?
explanation: The seller retains the title in a land contract. With a purchase money mortgage, the buyer retains the title.

topic: Property Valuation and Financial Analysis
question_text: With the cost approach to value, what is the replacement cost?
A: Cost of the materials used in construction
B: Cost to build a functionally equivalent improvement
C: Cost to build an exact replica of the subject, with the same materials and deficiencies
explanation: The replacement cost reflects the cost to build a functionally equivalent improvement, as opposed to the reproduction cost, which is the cost to build an exact replica of the subject, with the same materials and deficiencies.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: Which federal act makes phone solicitation to numbers on the Do Not Call Registry illegal unless a prior relationship or permission exists?
C: Do Not Call Implementation Act of 2003
explanation: The Do Not Call Implementation Act of 2003 makes phone solicitation illegal to numbers on the Do Not Call Registry unless a prior business relationship or permission exists.

topic: Contracts
question_text: You're helping prepare a sales contract for buyer clients. When is it acceptable for you to provide your clients with legal advice?
B: When explaining how to take title
D: When your broker is unavailable (as long as you verify the information afterward)
explanation: A licensee should never offer legal advice to clients unless the licensee is also a practicing attorney.

topic: Property Ownership and Land Use Controls and Regulations
question_text: Datums and benchmarks are used for ______.
explanation: Land surveyors use datums and benchmarks to measure elevations.

topic: Financing
question_text: What does it mean when someone agrees to do a "subject to" purchase, as seen in a situation where a buyer assists their neighbor facing foreclosure?
A: The buyer will co-sign a second mortgage with their neighbor so that they'll have the funds to pay off the first mortgage.
B: The buyer will purchase the home at the foreclosure auction and rent it to their neighbor at a reduced rate.
C: The buyer will sign an agreement with the lender to assume liability for the neighbor's loan.
D: The buyer will take over the neighbor's loan payments without telling their lender they're doing so.
explanation: When the new buyer makes the payments on a loan as if nothing has changed, this is called a "subject to" purchase.

topic: Financing
question_text: Scott is an MLO. Arthur, his assistant, does not have an MLO endorsement. Which of these activities must be performed by Scott?
A: Contacting a consumer to obtain tax returns or payroll receipts to verify loan application information
B: Explaining the steps the consumer needs to take to obtain a loan offer
C: Presenting a loan offer to a consumer for acceptance
D: Receiving a loan application through the mail and forwarding it, without review
explanation: Presenting a loan offer, whether the initial offer or a revised offer, is an MLO activity.

topic: Contracts
question_text: What phrase, when used in a real estate contract, reminds the parties to avoid unnecessary delays and to adhere to all contract dates?
C: Seek the advice of an attorney
explanation: "Time is of the essence" means that specific timeframes must be adhered to. If one party misses a deadline, that party is in breach of contract.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: A landlord refuses to show or rent an apartment to someone who is not Christian. What type of discrimination is this?
explanation: Showing a preference for or against a religious group, or showing intolerance for that group's observation of its religious practices or dietary habits, is religious discrimination.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
subtopic: Licensing and Continuing Education Requirements and Procedures
question_text: Which of the following describes a prepaid rental listing service (PRLS)?
A: A PRLS is a group of real estate licensees who only deal with residential property rentals.
B: A PRLS is a type of real estate brokerage.
C: A PRLS provides listings of residential properties available for rent to prospective tenants for a fee.
D: A PRLS represents landlords by marketing their properties to prospective tenants for a commission.
explanation: In exchange for a fee, a PRLS provides listings of residential real property available for rent to prospective tenants, but is not involved in negotiating lease or rental agreements.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
subtopic: Disclosure of Material Facts Affecting Property Value
question_text: What information about a property is the licensee required to disclose to potential buyers?
A: Any known or assumed information about a property
B: Any material, adverse information that the licensee has actual knowledge of concerning the physical condition of the property
C: Only information that the seller wants the licensee to share with prospective buyers
D: Only information that would make the property sell more quickly
explanation: A licensee is required to disclose any material, adverse information that the licensee has actual knowledge of concerning the physical condition of the property.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: Which of the following is an example of a tie-in arrangement?
A: A business offers add-on services for its best customers.
B: A business requires its clients to also purchase service.
C: Competing businesses agree to similar pricing strategies.
D: Competing companies agree to not do business with a third.
explanation: Tie-in arrangements are antitrust violations that involve predicating one service on the consumer purchasing another service.

topic: Property Valuation and Financial Analysis
question_text: Which of the following terms refers to the value a property holds for its owner based on how they currently use and enjoy it?
explanation: Value in use is the value of a property to the person currently using it, rather than to a typical buyer. For example, a family estate with generations of history is likely of more value to those living there than it would be to a new buyer.

topic: Contracts
question_text: Brynn's listing agent told potential buyers that all offers on Brynn's property would be considered at 5 p. m. on May 3. By that date and time, there were four offers. The persons making these offers are the ______.
explanation: The party making an offer is known as the offeror.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
subtopic: Disclosure of Material Facts Affecting Property Value
question_text: Three days ago, there was a severe thunderstorm in Shirley's town. Today, there's still a large puddle of water on her property, but it doesn't appear the neighboring properties have any puddles. This could indicate a(n) ______ problem.
explanation: Standing water can indicate a drainage problem if it remains for more than 24 hours after a heavy rain. Water should generally flow away from the home.

topic: Property Ownership and Land Use Controls and Regulations
question_text: The EPA has special requirements for contractors performing lead abatement or remodeling in "target" dwellings. These requirements relate to what?
A: Cost of the abatement or repairs
C: Safety precautions to protect occupants and workers from lead dust
explanation: "Target" dwellings have specific requirements for contractors performing lead abatement or remodeling.

topic: Contracts
question_text: Rex needs to handle some money he acquired during an "unsavory" business deal. He agrees to sign his boat over to his colleague, Ben, if Ben can launder the money and return it to Rex as part of a legal business deal. What kind of contract do Rex and Ben have?
explanation: A contract for an illegal purpose is void!

topic: Contracts
question_text: Margo is the potential buyer of the property in an option contract. Margo is the ______.
explanation: The potential buyer of the property in an option contract is known as the optionee.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: A mortgage lender has landed in hot water for fair housing discrimination. Which of these actions might have gotten the lender in trouble?
A: Denying a loan based on income-to-credit ratio
B: Denying a loan that was pre-approved after the mother stops working to care for her baby
C: Imposing different interest rates based on credit scores
D: Refusing to provide literature about loans to consumers with poor English language skills
explanation: It is illegal to withhold information about a loan on the basis of a protected class. While the case of the mother staying home may look like a familial protection, the denial is actually made on the basis of a lower income, which is a completely legal.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: May a real estate brokerage hire unlicensed assistants?
A: No, because every business activity at real estate brokerages requires a real estate license
B: No, because it's too risky in terms of activities they're legally permitted to perform
C: Yes, but only if the broker ensures that unlicensed people understand and stick to those activities they may legally perform without a license
D: Yes, but only with the state agency's approval
explanation: Brokers should be actively engaged in managing the brokerage and ensuring that any brokerage- related business is carried out competently and in accordance with local, state, and federal rules and regulations, including unlicensed activities.

topic: Laws of Agency and Fiduciary Duties
subtopic: Disclosure of Acting as Principal or Other Interest
question_text: You've been practicing real estate for a while and decide to purchase a property as an investment along with a business partner (who's not a real estate broker). Since you're a licensee, which of these actions must you take?
A: You must be represented by another broker in this transaction.
B: You must disclose your licensed status, any conflicts of interest, and any relevant facts that might affect the seller's decision to accept your offer to the seller.
C: You must offer the full list price, regardless of any other factors affecting the property value.
D: You must sign an agency agreement to represent your business partner before you can make an offer to the seller.
explanation: Your licensed status must be disclosed in writing, along with any conflicts of interest and all information that could affect the seller's decision to accept your offer, such as potential for profit.

topic: Transfer of Property
question_text: Paula is bidding on a property that's being sold at a foreclosure auction. She's excited about the great deal she's getting on the property after she finds out she submitted the winning bid. What could cause Paula's great deal to turn into a nightmare?
A: The lender has the option to refuse her bid and revoke the deed transferring ownership to Paula.
B: The previous owner may redeem the property by paying Paula at least 50% of the property's market value.
C: The title insurance company may charge her additional fees after closing to continue the title policy.
D: The title to the property may have hidden issues that could cost her a lot of money to clear.
explanation: Foreclosed properties are most likely to have hidden title issues, and the title generally isn't insurable. Paula may discover existing liens on the property she's now responsible for that could cost her a lot of money.

topic: Contracts
question_text: What's the key difference between assignment and novation of a contract?
A: Assignment releases the original party from all obligations, while novation does not.
B: Individual contracts must specifically allow novation, but not assignment.
C: Novation is disallowed in many states, while assignment is not.
D: Novation releases the original party from all obligations, while assignment does not.
explanation: Both assignment and novation may replace one party to a contract with a new party (or parties). But with novation, a new contract is created, so the original party is fully released from any obligations.

topic: Contracts
question_text: Gloria has an option to purchase the cottage she leases from her landlord. She can exercise the option within the next two years. To gain that right, Gloria paid the landlord $5,000. This is called ______.
explanation: The money that an optionee in an option contract is required to pay the optionor is known as an option fee.

topic: Transfer of Property
question_text: Capital gains fall into which stage of the property ownership life cycle?
B: Capital gains are not part of the property ownership life cycle.
explanation: Sellers may be liable for capital gains tax upon the reversion (sale) of property they own.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
subtopic: Licensing and Continuing Education Requirements and Procedures
question_text: In which of these scenarios would the consumer need a real estate license?
A: Jessie is searching for a new home for a friend moving into town, who will compensate her 2% of the sale price for her time and effort.
B: Mickey is selling his own home and isn't using the services of a listing agent.
C: Peter is helping his sister, Kristen, find a new apartment and will not be compensated in any way.
D: Ronald is acting as executor of his uncle's estate, which includes selling the property his uncle owned.
explanation: In general, unlicensed consumers can't perform real estate activities for others for a fee. Jessie is receiving compensation and would need to be licensed to accept this without breaking any laws.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: Because of the extreme importance of proper trust fund handling and recordkeeping, the _____________ conducts routine audits of brokers.
B: California Department of Real Estate Commissioner
explanation: The California Department of Real Estate Commissioner has this oversight responsibility.

topic: Property Valuation and Financial Analysis
question_text: Which category of appraiser can appraise one- to four-unit residential property valued under $1 million and that are not complex in nature, and non-residential properties valued below $250,000?
explanation: Residential licensees have limits on the residential and non-residential properties they can appraise. Residential properties must be no more than four units and valued under $1 million. Non-residential properties must be valued under $250,000.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: The Natural Hazard Disclosure statement is used for _____________.
A: All residential transactions, regardless of type of transfer
B: Residential transactions in rural areas only
C: Residential transactions that also require the TDS
D: Residential transactions that do not use the TDS
explanation: The NHD is used in the same kinds of residential transactions where the TDS is required, that is, one- to four-unit dwellings, manufactured homes, and condos.

topic: Property Valuation and Financial Analysis
question_text: A seller received an offer for $365,000, which is the price at which similar houses in the neighborhood are selling. What does this price represent?
explanation: Market value is the price at which a willing buyer and a willing seller would strike a deal, given normal market conditions.

topic: Transfer of Property
question_text: When is the Documentary Transfer Tax collected?
B: As soon as the documents are filed
D: On the first tax bill after the property has been sold
explanation: The Documentary Transfer tax is collected at the time of closing along with other closing costs.

topic: Property Valuation and Financial Analysis
question_text: Building codes, zoning laws, and environmental legislation are examples of which force that influences property value?
explanation: These are examples of political or government forces that influence value. These tend to deal with laws, policy, and codes.

topic: Laws of Agency and Fiduciary Duties
question_text: Before entering into an agency relationship with a consumer, what must a licensee do?
D: Provide an agency disclosure form and obtain signatures
explanation: Agency disclosure forms must be provided as soon as practicable, and before entering into an agency relationship.

topic: Property Valuation and Financial Analysis
question_text: You know a property's effective gross income and its operating expenses. How would you calculate the net operating income?
B: Multiply annual return by .05 of the property's value.
D: Subtract operating expenses from effective gross income.
explanation: Net operating income is effective gross income, minus operating expenses.

topic: Property Valuation and Financial Analysis
question_text: Which one of the following is a description of economic depreciation?
A: Investors can take a business deduction for annual depreciation.
B: The asset is worth less because the economy took a downturn.
C: The asset is worth more because of capital improvements.
D: The owner/investor is making less income from the property than previously.
explanation: Economic depreciation is an actual loss in value, whether it's from wear and tear (physical deterioration) or from external factors (for example, a fire damaged the building, there was a downturn in the local economy, or the business climate saw unfavorable changes).

topic: Property Valuation and Financial Analysis
question_text: Which element is applied last when using the sales comparison approach to value?
explanation: The elements considered in the sales comparison approach are applied in a specific order: financing terms and cash equivalency, conditions of sale, market conditions at the time of contract and closing, location, and physical characteristics.

topic: Laws of Agency and Fiduciary Duties
question_text: Taylor is the owner of a new apartment building. She has 15 units she needs to lease, so she has enlisted Pablo as her agent. Is Pablo required to give Taylor an agency disclosure form?
A: No, agency disclosure is not required for residential transactions involving five or more units.
B: No, agency disclosure is only required for commercial transactions.
C: No, agency disclosure is only required on sales of residential properties.
D: Yes, agency disclosure is required for lease transactions.
explanation: Agency disclosure is not required for transactions involving residential properties with five or more units, which are exempt from this disclosure requirement.

topic: Property Valuation and Financial Analysis
question_text: Which of these properties are exempt from the FIRREA federal appraisal guidelines?
explanation: Properties valued at $400,000 or less are exempt from federal appraisal requirements in federally related transactions .

topic: Laws of Agency and Fiduciary Duties
subtopic: Law, Definition and Nature of Agency Relationships, Types of Agencies, and Agents
question_text: You have an agency agreement with Sam to list his property for sale. Because of this, what is Sam's relationship to you?
explanation: An agency agreement exists, which makes Sam your client.

topic: Laws of Agency and Fiduciary Duties
question_text: Gillian is a real estate licensee who attends a party at the home of a mortgage broker, Tim, with whom she has worked in the past. At the party, Tim offers Gillian tickets to a concert, saying that he can't use them. She accepts gladly, and laughs when Tim says as he hands the tickets over, "And all I ask in return is that you send a customer or two my way!" Is Gillian guilty of a violation?
C: Not unless she neglects to disclose the exchange and the value of the tickets to her broker within three days.
D: Yes, Gillian is guilty because she has accepted what is essentially a referral fee from a mortgage broker.
explanation: An agent may not receive referral fees or gifts from mortgage brokers, title reps, etc.

topic: Laws of Agency and Fiduciary Duties
question_text: Under which of the following circumstances would the client and agent most likely mutually agree to terminate a listing?
A: A buyer approached the seller with a much higher offer than the current listing price.
B: The agent and client don't agree on the best way to price, maintain, and market the property.
C: The client has found a buyer and wants to avoid paying a commission.
D: The client's cousin just became licensed and needs her first listing.
explanation: When an agent and seller client can't agree on important aspects of selling the property, the relationship will not benefit anyone. Mutual termination is a valid way to terminate the agency agreement.

topic: Property Valuation and Financial Analysis
question_text: Which economic principle is in play when the smallest property's value increases because it's surrounded by higher-value properties?
explanation: Progression is the bump in value that a lower-value property gets by being near a higher-value property.

topic: Laws of Agency and Fiduciary Duties
question_text: Candace and Phil Tolson listed their home for sale with Trent Richards, the broker for Richards Homes. Sadly, Trent became incapacitated due to a car accident. What's the status of the listing agreement?
A: Because the listing agreement is with the brokerage firm, the agreement continues.
B: The agreement terminates by operation of law.
C: The brokerage firm can agree to terminate the agreement if the Tolsons choose to not work with another agent.
D: The Tolsons may choose to terminate the agency agreement.
explanation: Because the broker has become incapacitated, the listing agreement terminates by operation of law.

topic: Property Valuation and Financial Analysis
question_text: What do you do to determine debt coverage ratio?
A: Divide debt service by gross income
B: Divide net income by debt service
explanation: Divide net income by debt service to get the debt coverage ratio.

topic: Property Valuation and Financial Analysis
question_text: Which economic principle is at work when a property's value increases because a neighboring property has increased in value?
explanation: When the value of a property increases thanks to an adjacent higher-quality property, this is called progression.

topic: Property Valuation and Financial Analysis
question_text: What economic principle says that a property's value is determined by what it would cost to purchase a similar property?
explanation: The principle of substitution assumes that a reasonable person wouldn't pay more for a nearly identical property; therefore, the price of similar properties influences a given property's market value.

topic: Laws of Agency and Fiduciary Duties
question_text: Jim from Greater SW Realty represents Andy as the buyer of a parcel of land. Roger, also from Greater SW Realty, has the listing for that land. Is this a dual agency situation?
A: No, because each party has their own representation.
B: No, because land is not subject to dual agency requirements.
C: Yes, because any time more than one party is involved in a transaction, it is dual agency.
D: Yes, because both Jim and Roger work for the same broker.
explanation: Remember that listings belong to the broker. The same broker represents both sides of this transaction.

topic: Laws of Agency and Fiduciary Duties
question_text: Ginnie's Aunt Becca listed the old family mansion with Ginnie. Ginnie put it on the market for Becca, but then she and her cousins talked with Becca and decided they wanted to keep the property in the family. What's the best way to terminate the agreement?
B: Ginnie and Becca can mutually agree to terminate the agreement.
D: They should wait for the listing to expire.
explanation: The most appropriate way to terminate the listing is to mutually agree to the termination.

topic: Laws of Agency and Fiduciary Duties
question_text: Which of these is NOT one of the ways in which an agency relationship may be terminated without penalty for either the agent or the principal?
A: Delaney signed a buyer's representation agreement with Martha. After Delaney made an offer on a house, she changed her mind and terminated the agency agreement.
B: Martha listed Sonja's home for sale. Martha helped Sonja negotiate an offer and performed the other tasks required of her. The closing has taken place.
C: Phyllis listed her home with Brad. Brad put the property on the MLS, but Phyllis hasn't heard from him in more than two months.
D: Richard listed Ole's ski chalet for sale. Two weeks later, an avalanche destroyed the property.
explanation: Unless Martha agrees to terminate the agency agreement with Delaney, Delaney may still owe Martha the agreed-upon compensation for breaching this agreement.

topic: Property Valuation and Financial Analysis
question_text: Which of the following is a true statement about how adjustments are made in the sales comparison approach?
A: Adjustments are made to the subject property, not the comparables.
B: Appraisers adjust downward when a comparable is missing a feature found in the subject property.
C: Appraisers adjust upward when a comparable is missing a feature found in the subject property.
D: Only three adjustments per comparable property are allowed; otherwise it's not considered sufficiently similar.
explanation: All adjustments are made to the comparable properties' sales prices to make them as similar as possible to the subject property.

topic: Laws of Agency and Fiduciary Duties
question_text: If an agent lists a home for his sister and it sells, can the agent accept his compensation directly from his sister?
A: No, agents cannot accept compensation from immediate family.
B: No, the compensation must go through the agent's broker.
C: No, the compensation must go through the escrow company first.
D: Yes, because she's a close relative.
explanation: All compensation related to real estate must come through the agent's broker.

topic: Property Valuation and Financial Analysis
question_text: What has occurred when the increased value of homes in an area result in increased value for all homes in that area?
explanation: Progression is the economic principle that lower-quality properties gain value simply by being near higher-quality properties.

topic: Laws of Agency and Fiduciary Duties
subtopic: Creation of Agency and Agency Agreements
question_text: Joe signed a listing agreement with Marisa. A week later, Marisa's co-worker, Tina, showed Joe a property that he's interested in buying once his home sells. A week after that, Ross submitted an offer on Joe's property on behalf of his buyer client. Who is Joe's agent?
explanation: The listing agreement acts as the agency agreement between the seller and the licensee, so Marisa is Joe's agent and representative.

topic: Property Valuation and Financial Analysis
question_text: Which category of appraiser can appraise any real property without any limitations related to value or complexity?
explanation: Certified general appraisers can appraise residential and non-residential properties of any value and any complexity. This appraiser category has the greatest amount of education and experience.

topic: Property Valuation and Financial Analysis
question_text: The economic principle that tells us that when supply goes up, price goes down is also called ______.
explanation: Supply and demand says that when supply goes up, prices go down because there is less demand.

topic: Laws of Agency and Fiduciary Duties
question_text: What happens if a client terminates a listing agreement before its expiration date?
A: The agent must send the client a notice of release form.
C: The client may owe a commission anyway.
explanation: The listing agreement may not be cancelled by only one party. It's possible the client will owe the agent the commission.

topic: Property Valuation and Financial Analysis
question_text: In investments, there are two types of depreciation, and each is defined by a particular event. Which of the following most accurately pairs the depreciation type with the event it is tied to?
explanation: Tax depreciation is tied to cost recovery.

topic: Laws of Agency and Fiduciary Duties
question_text: Cheri, a licensee, refuses to negotiate for either party in her dual agency transaction. What might happen to Cheri?
B: She can be cited for failure to perform.
C: She can be sanctioned for breach of contract.
D: She may lose her license; this is a flagrant violation of licensee duties.
explanation: In a dual agency situation, a licensee may not negotiate for or advocate for either party.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: Jared is your client who is selling his four-bedroom home. When you ask him if he is aware of any physical defects with the property, he states that the property is "in fine shape." Yet you've noticed several issues with rotted doorsills, crumbling masonry, and a suspicious moisture stain on the ceiling. If Jared won't come clean about issues of property condition, what should you do?
B: Find ways to hide the issues that you noticed so that potential buyers won't see them
C: Have Jared sign a waiver so that you cannot be held liable for issues he does not disclose
D: Have the buyer sign a waiver so that you cannot be held liable for issues he does not disclose
explanation: If a seller is evasive about issues with property condition, make sure that you educate them on the seller's legal obligation to disclose. If you still can't obtain cooperation, you should decline the listing.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: In California, which repair can a landlord legally postpone?
A: A tenant clogged up a toilet and does not have a plunger.
B: A tenant does not have running water to their shower.
C: A tenant's key broke in the deadbolt, and the front door does not lock.
D: A tenant's lights and outlets aren't working in their kitchen.
explanation: When a tenant causes damage, it may be the tenant's responsibility to fix it.

topic: Property Ownership and Land Use Controls and Regulations
question_text: Terry purchases a property. The deed includes a description of an easement given to the neighboring property. This is an easement created by ______.
explanation: An easement created by express written language in a deed is created by express grant.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: You're walking through a property with a new seller client. The seller tells you that the property is serviced by the public sewer system, but when walking up the drive you noticed the access hatch for a septic system. What should you do?
A: Believe the homeowner when he says the property is on public sewer, because he'd know best.
B: Hire a private investigator to look into it.
C: Inquire about the homeowner's claim to ensure the property really is on public sewer.
D: Terminate the listing, as the homeowner is obviously not being truthful.
explanation: As an agent, it's your responsibility to investigate any discrepancies of a material nature, but that doesn't mean hiring a private investigator.

topic: Contracts
question_text: Drew and Hank were camping at Hank's riverfront cabin. Hank told Drew that he rarely used the cabin and was thinking of selling it. Drew said that he'd buy it from Hank for $80,000, which Hank agreed was a fair price. It's two months later, and Hank is upset that Drew now says he won't buy it. Why isn't this contract enforceable?
A: Drew didn't have the financial resources to make the offer.
B: Real estate contracts must be in writing.
C: There was no offer and acceptance.
explanation: The statute of frauds requires that real estate contracts be in writing. Drew's offer was oral and thus didn't create an enforceable contract.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: Josefina is a new licensee starting at a brokerage where she is the only Hispanic and the only person who speaks both Spanish and English. How does this make her an asset to the brokerage?
A: She can shadow more experienced agents and help them with their work.
B: She can work with Spanish speaking clients more easily than other licensees can.
C: She is new and can be molded to the ways of the brokerage.
D: She will bring in clients from her extended family and social connections.
explanation: Each licensee has a cultural background that will contribute uniquely to the brokerage, but being bilingual can be especially useful in working successfully with more clients.

topic: Contracts
question_text: Amy is working with seller clients who have suggested they would like the property to go to another African-American family. Which section of the listing agreement would help Amy convey why she cannot market the property this way?
explanation: The only section included here that is actually found in the C.A.R. Form RLA is equal housing opportunity, which states that the broker adheres to anti-discrimination laws.

topic: Contracts
question_text: Kendra made an offer on Sam's property. Sam rejected Kendra's offer, but made a counter-offer. Kendra is now considering the counter. What role does Kendra currently have in this scenario?
explanation: The seller considering a buyer's offer is an offeree, but if that seller makes a counter-offer, then the seller becomes the offeror, and the buyer becomes an offeree.
